lg.l: Dear poet, who sang of the forest primeval,
lg.note: The poem addresses Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, author of Evangeline, A Tale of Acadie (1847)
lg.l: Leaving the gay world, I’d wander with thee—
Ay, wander afar, where no castle medieval
Rears its gray turrets on crags by the sea,
Seeking the shade of the great Kauri-tree.
Dear poet, who sang of the forest primeval,
Reared in its silence, impressive, profound,
When axes, the echoes of Lebanon waking,
lg.note: The Bible describes King Solomon's use of Lebanese cedars in the construction of the Temple (1 Kings 5).
lg.l: Felled her proud cedars in scores to the ground,
Thy leaves were unstirred by a treacherous sound.
When Gothic wolves ravaged the banks of old Tiber,
lg.note: Possibly a reference to the Sack of Rome in 546 C.E., during the Gothic War.
lg.l: When Druids’ dread holocaust smirched Britain’s sky,
lg.note: Burnt human sacrifice was attributed to the Druidic culture of Pre-Roman Britain.
lg.l: When the halter of Judas was growing green fibre,
lg.note: The Bible records that Judas Iscariot hanged himself after betraying Jesus Christ (Matthew 27:5).
lg.l: When zealous Crusaders to Achoe drew nigh,
lg.note: Likely a reference to the conquest of the city of Acre in 1191 C.E., during the Third Crusade.
lg.l: Undreamt of, remote, passed thy lone infancy.
When once-favoured Raleigh in prison lay pining,
lg.note: Sir Walter Raleigh was knighted by Queen Elizabeth in 1585, but was imprisoned by her in the Tower of London in 1591 for marrying without her permission.
lg.l: When Plymouth folk wept as the stanch Mayflower sailed,
lg.note: A reference to the Pilgrim settlers who sailed for North America in 1620.
lg.l: When fires of rebellion from Versaille were shining,
When vengeance the grim, frowning Bastille assailed,
lg.note: Versaille and the Bastille were pivotal locations during the French Revolution of 1789.
lg.l: Earth-fed and sun-strengthened, thy stature prevailed.
When Liberty, outraged, in anger and sorrow,
Blew her loud reveille o’er Florida’s flowers,
lg.note: Likely a reference to the American revolutionary war, 1775-1783.
lg.l: Each day was as calm as its placid to-morrow,
Gliding white-souled through these virginal bowers:
In soundless procession past thee trooped the hours.
O glory of nature! O relic of ages!
Firm as the granite thou seemest to be.
Still harmlessly round thee the tempest oft rages;
Long may the fire-fiend be warded from thee,
lg.note: A reference to the prevalence of forest fires in colonial New Zealand.
lg.l: Long may the life-sap still rise in our tree!
Old England may boast of her oak-trees that flourish
On woodland and lea, and exult in their fame;
California’s bayou and canon may nourish
Proud Wellingtonia’s i.e. redwood unrivalled claim—
Towards thee Thames Waiotahi Creek, mentioned in the poem's title, is in the Thames region of the North Island of New Zealand. hearts will beat ever the same.
Hist! Hark! From thy top growth that melody falling,
Dulcet, staccato, scarce heard, ere ‘tis done—
The shy Korimako Korimako. Also known as the bellbird due to its melodious call. its shyer mate calling
With bell note to vespers at setting of sun,
Ere Kiwi and Morepork Morepork. The ruru, a New Zealand species of owl. cries have begun.
Dear poet, who sang of the forest primeval,
Oh, had thy mantle but fallen on me—
Even though I dwell where no castle medieval
Rears its gray turrets on crags by the sea—
Fame, like the Rata, Rata. A species of tree, infamous for beginning its life as an epiphyte that strangles its host tree as its roots grow down to the ground. had wreathed our grand tree.
